results.title: Beef cattle in Australia
results.creator_credit: Cine Australian Productions and Fred Whatham
results.brief_description: A concise description of the Australian beef cattle industry, covering such aspects as marketing, breeding, mustering and transportation. Narrated by Roger Climpson.
results.description: A concise description of the Australian beef cattle industry, covering such aspects as marketing, breeding, mustering and transportation. Narrated by Roger Climpson.

results.title: Beef business
results.creator_credit: British Information Services, Wallace Productions, A. Frank Bundy and B. Salt
results.brief_description: A film showing the best ways of making beef production profitable through different methods of grazing, feeding, breeding and marketing.

results.title: Beef background
results.brief_description: Describes the production of fine cattle and quality beef in Australia for domestic and overseas markets. Includes the angus, devon, hereford and santa catrudez breeds. Narrated by Barry Brady.
results.description: Describes the production of fine cattle and quality beef in Australia for domestic and overseas markets. Includes the angus, devon, hereford and santa catrudez breeds. Narrated by Barry Brady.

results.title: Beef and dairy insemination program
results.brief_description: Describes the artificial insemination program at Bacchus Marsh. Outlines methods of collection, selection and storage as well as service to cows.

results.title: Beechworth Victoria
results.brief_description: Shows Australia’s oldest gold mining town, Beechworth through the eyes of a visiting young couple. No other credits available.

results.title: Beech foresters
results.brief_description: This film reviews the extent and nature of beech forests in New Zealand and describes schemes undertaken for improvement. Draws attention to the work of the New Zealand Forest Service in carrying out aerial and ground surveys and compiling information, resulting in such schemes as the erection of deer-proof fences, selection of seed trees and the establishment of even age forests. Describes the uses to which timber is put. No other credits available.
results.description: This film reviews the extent and nature of beech forests in New Zealand and describes schemes undertaken for improvement. Describes the uses to which timber is put. No other credits available.

results.title: Bedtime stories
results.creator_credit: International Video Books and Gerben Cath
results.brief_description: Introduces Dorothy Butler who passionately believes books should play a crucial role in children’s lives. Attempts to encourage children to read, by capitalising on their fascination with the television screen. Uses professional storytellers and well-known stories, giving fully annotated details for each book used.

results.title: Bedouins of Arabia
results.creator_credit: Institut für Film und Bild and Richard Taylor
results.brief_description: Portrays the life of Bedouin tribesmen in the Arabian desert, noting their relationships with each other and with the land. Suitable for upper primary and secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Bedlam
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures, Val Lewton and Mark Robson
results.brief_description: A dramatic and sinister psychodrama from horror film producer Val Lewton, who was also responsible for bringing classics such as “Cat people” (1942), “The Leopard man” (1943), “The Ghost ship” (1943), “The Body snatcher” (1945) and “Isle of the dead” (1945) to the big screen. In 18th century London, paradoxically named the Age of Reason by the people, a popular past-time for upper classes was to visit St. Mary’s of Bethlehem Asylum - “Bedlam” - to observe its “loonies”. After the death of a young poet attempting to escape Bedlam leaves the wealthy Lord Mortimer without a commissioned play, the sinister head of the Asylum, Master George Sims, steps in and offers to stage a mask performed by the inmates of his Asylum. Intrigued, Mortimer’s young protege Mistress Nell Bowen decides to pay the Asylum a visit, but becomes rapidly disgusted and offended by Sims’ brutal and sadistic treatment of the inmates. With advice from Quaker stonemason William Hannay, she resolves to stop the mistreatment and bring about reform. However, her plans go awry when Sims manages to turn Lord Mortimer against her, and then has her committed to Bedlam. Shunned by those whom she once called friends, Nell finds friendship and hope among the tortured souls imprisoned in the madhouse, and her quest to reform the system becomes more urgent. However, the inmates have their own ideas about reform, and justice is served to their cruel tormentor in a most macabre manner, in a scene lifted from Edgar Allen Poe. Fascinating to note is that one of the reasons given as to why a particular inmate was confined, was due to his desire to create ‘moving pictures’. Bedlam, written by Lewton under a pseudonym and inspired by William Hogarth’s satirical series of engravings entitled, “A Rakes’s Progress” (1735), represents a marked shift away from the sensationalist b-movies he produced in the early 40’s , and was his last offering in the horror genre before his death in 1951. Cast includes Boris Karloff, Anna Lee.
